text: [Music]
[Music]
So, um I really consider myself um a
storyteller.
But um I don't really tell stories in
the usual way in the sense that I don't
usually tell my own stories. Um instead
I'm really interested in building tools
that allow large numbers of uh other
people to tell their stories. Uh people
all around the world. Um I I do this
because I think that um I think people
actually have a lot in common. I think
people are very similar. But I also
think that we have trouble seeing that.
uh you know as I look around the world I
see a lot of gaps and I think we all see
a lot of gaps um and we we define
ourselves by our gaps uh you know there
there's language gaps uh there's
ethnicity and racial gaps there's uh
there's age gaps there's gender gaps
there's sexuality gaps there's wealth
and uh and money gaps there's education
gaps
uh there's also uh religious gaps you
know we have all these gaps and I I
think we like our gaps because they make
us feel like we identify with something
some smaller community. But uh I think
that actually despite our gaps uh we
really have a lot in common and uh I
think one thing we have in common uh is
a very deep need to express ourselves. I
think this is a very uh old uh human
desire. Um it's nothing new. Uh but the
thing about self-expression is that
there's traditionally been this
imbalance between the desire that we
have to express ourselves and the number
of sympathetic friends who are willing
to stand around and listen.
Uh this also is nothing new. Uh since
the dawn of of human history, we've
tried to rectify this imbalance by uh
making art, writing poems, singing
songs, scripting editorials, and sending
them into a newspaper, gossiping with
friends. This is nothing new. What's new
is that in the last several years, a lot
of these very traditional physical human
activities, these acts of
self-expression have been moving on to
the internet. Uh and as that's happened,
uh people have been leaving behind
footprints. footprints that tell stories
of their moments of self-expression. And
so what I do is I uh I write computer
programs that study very large sets of
these footprints and then try to draw uh
conclusions about the people who left
them. Uh what they feel, what they
think, uh what's different in the world
today than usual. Uh these sorts of
questions. Uh one project that explores
these ideas uh which was made about a
year ago is a piece called We Feel Fine.
Uh this is a piece that uh every 2 or 3
minutes scans the world's newly posted
blog entries for occurrences of the
phrases I feel or I am feeling. And when
it finds one of those phrases, it grabs
the sentence up to the period and then
automatically tries to deduce the age,
gender, and geographical location of the
person that wrote that sentence. Uh then
knowing the geographical location and
the time, we can also then figure out
the weather when that person wrote the
sentence. All of this information is
saved in a database that collects about
20,000 feelings a day. Uh it's been
running for about a year and a half. Uh
it's reached about 7 and a half million
human feelings now. Uh and I'll show you
a glimpse of of how this information is
then uh visualized. Uh so this is we
feel fine. What you see here are uh a
madly swarming mass of particles each of
which represents a single human feeling
that was stated in the last few hours.
The color of each particle corresponds
to the type of feeling inside. So that
happy positive feelings are brightly
colored and sad negative feelings are
darkly colored. Uh the diameter of each
dot represents the length of the
sentence inside so that the large dots
contain large sentences and the small
dots contain small sentences. Any dot
can be clicked and expanded. And we see
here uh I would just feel so much better
if I could curl up in his arms right now
and feel his affection for me and the
embrace of his body and the tenderness
of his lips. So it gets pretty hot and
steamy sometimes in the world of human
emotions. And all of these are stated by
uh people. I I know that objectively it
really doesn't mean much, but after
spending so many years as a small fish
in a big pond, it's nice to feel bigger
again. The dots exhibit human qualities.
They they kind of have uh their own
physics and they swarm wildly around uh
kind of exploring the world uh of life.
Um and then they also exhibit curiosity.
You can see a few of them are swarming
around the cursor right now. Uh you can
see some other ones are swarming around
the bottom left corner of the screen
around uh six words. Those six words
represent the six movements of we feel
fine. Uh we're currently seeing madness.
There's also murmurss, montage, mobs,
metrics, and mounds. And I'll walk you
through a few of those. Now, murmurss uh
causes all of the feelings to fly to the
ceiling. And then one by one in reverse
chronological order, they excuse
themselves, entering this scrolling list
of of feelings.
I feel a bit better now.
I feel confused and unsure of what the
hell I want to do. I feel jipped out of
something awesome here. I feel so free.
I feel so good. I feel like I'm in this
fog of depression that I can't get out
of. And you can click any of these to go
out and visit the blog uh from which it
was collected. And in that way, you can
connect with the authors of these
statements uh if you feel some degree of
empathy.
The next movement is called montage. Uh
montage causes all of the feelings that
contain photographs uh to uh become
extracted and display themselves in a in
a grid. Uh, this grid is then said to
represent the picture of the world's
feelings in the last few hours, if you
will. Each of these, uh, can be clicked
and we can blow it up. We see, uh, I
just feel like I'm not going to have fun
if it's not the both of us. That was
from someone in, uh, in Michigan.
Uh, we see,
I feel like I have been at a computer
all day.
These are automatically constructed
using the found objects. I I think I
feel a little full.
The next movement is called Mobs. Uh
Mobs provides different uh statistical
breakdowns of the population of of the
world's feelings in the last few hours.
We see that better is the most frequent
feeling right now, followed by good,
bad, guilty, right, down, sick, and so
on. We can also get a gender breakdown,
and we see that women are slightly more
prolific talking about their emotions in
the last few hours than men. Uh we can
do an age breakdown, which gives us a
histogram of the world's emotional uh
distribution by age. We see people in
their uh in their 20s are the most
prolific, followed by teenagers and then
people in their 30s and it dies out very
quickly from there. In weather, uh the
feelings assume the physical
characteristics of the weather that they
represent. So that uh the ones collected
on a sunny day swirl around as if
they're part of a sun. The cloudy ones
float along as if they're on a breeze.
The rainy ones fall down as if they're
in a rainstorm. And the snowy ones kind
of flutter to the ground. Finally,
location causes the feelings to move to
their positions on a world map showing
the geographical distribution of of
feelings.
Metrics provides more numerical views on
the data. We see that the world is
feeling used at 3.3 times the normal
level right now.
They're feeling warm at 2.9 times the
normal level and so on. Other views are
also available here. Gender, age,
weather, location. The final uh movement
is called mounds. It's a bit different
from the others. Mounds uh visualizes
the entire data set as large gelotinous
blobs which kind of jiggle. Uh and if I
hold down my cursor, they do a little
dance. Uh we see better is the most
frequent feeling uh followed by bad. And
then if I go over here, uh the list
begins to scroll and there's actually
thousands of feelings that have been
collected. You can see the little pink
cursor moving along representing our
position. Here we see people that feel
slipping, uh nauseous, responsible.
There's also a search capability if
you're interested in finding out about a
certain population. For instance, you
could find women who feel addicted uh in
their 20s when it was cloudy uh in
Bangladesh. Um
but I'll I'll spare you that. So, here
are some of my favorite uh montages that
have been collected. I feel so much of
my dad alive in me that there isn't even
room for me.
I feel very lonely.
I need to be in some backwoods redneck
town so that I can feel beautiful.
I feel invisible to you.
I wouldn't hide it if society didn't
make me feel like I needed to.
I feel in love with Carolyn.
I feel so naughty.
I feel these weirdos are actually an
asset to college life.
I love how I feel today.
So, as you can see, we feel fine uses a
technique that I call passive
observation. What I mean by that is that
it passively observes people as they
live their lives. Uh, it it scans the
world's blogs and looks at what people
are writing. Uh, and these people don't
know they're being watched or
interviewed. Uh, and because of that,
you end up getting very honest, candid,
sincere responses that are often very
moving. Um, and this is a technique that
I usually prefer in my work because
people don't know they're being
interviewed. They're just living life.
Uh, and they end up uh just acting like
that. Another technique is directly
questioning people. And this is a
technique that I explored in a different
project uh the Yahoo time capsule which
uh was designed to take a fingerprint of
the world in 2006. Uh it was divided
into 10 very simple themes. Love, anger,
sadness and so on. Each of which
contained a single very open-ended
question put to the world. What do you
love? What makes you angry? What makes
you sad? What do you believe in? And so
on. The time capsule was available for 1
month online translated into 10
languages. Um and uh this is what it
looked like. It's a spinning globe uh
the surface of which is entirely
composed of the pictures and words and
drawings of people that submitted to the
time capsule. The 10 themes radiate out
and orbit the time capsule. You can sift
through this this data and see uh what
people have submitted. This is in
response to what's beautiful this world.
There are two modes to the time capsule.
There's one world which presents the
spinning globe and many voices which uh
splits the data out into film strips and
lets you sift through them one by one.
Uh so this project was um punctuated by
a really uh amazing event um which was
held in the desert um in outside
Albuquerque in New Mexico at the James
PBLO where for three consecutive nights
the contents of the time capsule were
projected onto the sides of the ancient
Red Rock Canyon walls which stand about
200 ft tall. It was really incredible
and we also projected the contents of
the time capsule as binary code using a
35 W laser into outer space. You can see
the orange line leaving the desert floor
at about a 45Â°ree angle there. This was
amazing because uh the first night I
looked at all this information and
really started uh seeing the gaps that I
talked about earlier, the differences in
age, gender, and wealth and so on. Um
but you know, as I looked at this more
and more and more and saw these images
go across the rocks, I realized I was
seeing the same archetypal events
depicted again and again and again. You
know, weddings, births, uh funerals, the
first car, the first kiss, the first
camel or horse, depending on the
culture. Uh and um it was really moving
and and um this picture here was taken
the final night u from a distant cliff
about two miles away where the contents
of the capsule were being beamed into
space. And there was something very
moving about all of this human
expression being shot up into the night
sky. And it started to make me think a
lot about the night sky and how humans
have always used the night sky to
project their great stories. You know,
as a child in Vermont on a farm where I
grew up, uh I would often look up into
the dark sky and see the three star belt
of Orion the Hunter. And as an adult,
I've been more aware of the great Greek
myths playing out in the sky overhead
every night. Uh, you know, Orion facing
the roaring bull, Perseus flying to the
rescue of Andromeda, Zeus battling
Kronos for control of Mount Olympus. I
mean, these are the great uh tales of
the Greeks. And it caused me to wonder
about our world today. Uh, and it caused
me to wonder specifically if we could
make new constellations today, what
would those look like? What would those
be? If we could make new pictures in the
sky, what would we draw? What are the
great stories of today? And those are
the questions that inspired uh my new
project uh which is debuting here today
at TED. Nobody's seen this yet publicly.
Uh it's called Universe um revealing our
modern mythology. Uh and it uses this
metaphor of a of an interactive night
sky. So it's my great pleasure now to
show this to you. So universe will open
here and you'll see that it leads with a
uh a shifting starfield
and there's an aurora borealis in the
background kind of morphing with color.
The color of the Aurora Borealis can be
controlled using the single bar of color
at the bottom. And uh and we'll put it
down here to red. So you see this kind
of these stars moving along. Now uh
these aren't just uh little points of
light, little pixels. Each of those
stars actually represents a specific
event in the real world, a quote that
was stated by somebody, uh an image, uh
a news story, a person, a company, uh
you know, some kind of uh heroic
personality. Um, and you might notice
that as the cursor begins to touch some
of these uh stars that shapes begin to
emerge. We see here there's a little a
little man walking along or or maybe a
woman. And and we see here a uh a
photograph uh with a head. Um you can
start to see words emerging here. And uh
those are the constellations. Those are
the constellations of today. Um and I
can turn them all on and you can see
them moving across the sky. Now this is
the universe of 2007, the last two
months. The data from this is global
news coverage from thousands of news
sources around the world. It's using uh
the API of a really great uh company
that I work with in New York actually
called Dayife. Um and it's uh it's kind
of the zeitgeist view at this level of
uh of the world's uh current mythology
over the last couple months. So we can
see words emerging here like president,
Ford, um Iraq, Bush. And we can actually
isolate just the words. I call them
secrets and we can cause them to form an
alphabetical list. And we see Anna
Nicole Smith playing a big role
recently. Uh, President Ford. Uh, this
is Gerald Ford's funeral. We can uh
actually click anything in universe and
have it become the center of the
universe and everything else will enter
its orbit. So we'll click forward. Uh,
and now that becomes the center and the
things that relate to Ford uh, enter its
orbit and swirl around it. Uh, we can
isolate just the photographs and we now
see those. Um, we can click on one of
those and have the photograph be the
center of the universe. Uh now the
things that relate to it are swirling
around. We can click on this and uh we
see this iconic image of Betty Ford
kissing her husband's uh coffin. In
universe uh there's kind of no end. It
just kind of goes infinitely. Uh and you
can just kind of click on stuff. Uh this
is uh this is a photographic
representation called snapshots. But we
can actually uh be more specific in
defining our universe. So if we want to
let's check out what uh Bill Clinton's
universe looks like. and let's say in
the past week um what he's been up to.
So now we have a new universe which is
just constrained to all things Bill
Clinton. Uh we can have his
constellations emerge here. We can pull
out his secrets and we see that uh it
has a lot to do with candidates,
Hillary, presidential Barack Obama. Um
we can see the stories uh that Bill
Clinton is uh taking part in right now.
Uh any of those can be opened up. So we
see Obama and the Clintons meet in
Alabama. Uh you can see that this is an
important story. There's a lot of things
in its orbit. Uh if we open this up uh
we get different perspectives on this
story. You can click any of those to go
out and read the article at the the
source. This one's from Alazer.
We can also see the superstars. Uh these
would be the uh the the people that are
kind of the looming heroes and heroins
in the universe of Bill Clinton. So
there's Bill Clinton, Hillary, Iraq,
George Bush, uh Barack Obama, Scooter
Libby. These are kind of the the people
of Bill Clinton. Um, we can also see uh
a world map. So, this shows us the
geographic reach of Bill Clinton in the
last week or so. We can see he's been
focused in America because he's been
campaigning probably, but a little bit
of action over here in the Middle East.
Uh, and then we can also see a timeline.
So, uh, we see that he was a bit quiet
on Saturday, but he was back to work on
Sunday morning and, uh, actually been
tapering off since then this week. And
it's not limited to just people or
dates, but we can actually put in
concepts also. So, if I put in climate
change for all of 2006,
uh we'll see what that universe looks
like. Here we have our starfield. Here
we have our shapes. Here we have our
secrets. Uh so we see again climate
change is large. Nairobi uh global
conference environmental and uh there's
also quotes that you can see if you're
interested in reading about quotes on
climate change. You know, this is really
an infinite thing. uh the superstars of
climate change in 2006, United States,
Britain, China, uh you know, these are
the towering countries that kind of
define this concept. So, uh this is a
piece that demands exploration. This
will be online uh in several days,
probably next Tuesday. Uh and you'll all
be able to use it um and uh kind of
explore what your own personal mythology
might be. You'll notice that in day life
it's rather in universe it supports both
the notion of a global mythology which
is represented by something as broad as
say 2007 and also a personal mythology
as you search for the things that uh
that are important to you in your world.
Uh and then uh see what the
constellations of those might look like.
Uh so uh it's been a pleasure. Thank you
very much. Um and uh thanks
